Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: blue grey leather book
A blue grey leather book on A Catalogue and Guide to Sword Smithing.
A blue grey leather book on A Catalogue and Guide to Sword Smithing.

A blue grey leather book. On the upper portion of the cover is the title 'A Catalogue and Guide to Sword Smithing' and printed smaller beneath it are the words 'edited and compiled by Master Incudine, Steelsmith of the Avoirdupois'. The border of the cover neatly displays an embossed trail of various weaponry.

Table of Contents

- chapter 1: low grade swords (page 3)

Contents:
- Introduction to swordsmithing (page 2)
- chapter 1: low grade swords (page 3)
- chapter 2: high grade swords (page 4)
- chapter 3: low grade fencing swords.(page 5)
- chapter 4: high end fencing weapons.(page 6)
- chapter 5: hilts (page 7)
Introduction to Swordsmithing

Welcome to the wide world of Sword Weaponry!
Inside is a near complete listing of blueprints and instruction manuals with how to construct and make Swords of various types as well as hilts to match. This guide can serve to teach apprentices through study, as well as serve as a Catalogue for customers.
Every sword, with hilt included, will use about half a rod, or 5 feet. Each weapon should be selected and treated with care. Depending on the individual preferences, some weapons are better suited to bulky strong individuals, Limber and althetic agile fighters, or the quick reflexes of the speedy.
This guide does not instruct on which weapon is best suited for the style of the fighter, it is up to that person to master their abilities and decide what works best for them.
Good luck, and Train hard!

Welcome to the wide world of Sword Weaponry!
Inside is a near complete listing of blueprints and instruction manuals with how to construct and make Swords of various types as well as hilts to match. This guide can serve to teach apprentices through study, as well as serve as a Catalogue for customers.
Every sword, with hilt included, will use about half a rod, or 5 feet. Each weapon should be selected and treated with care. Depending on the individual preferences, some weapons are better suited to bulky strong individuals, Limber and althetic agile fighters, or the quick reflexes of the speedy.
This guide does not instruct on which weapon is best suited for the style of the fighter, it is up to that person to master their abilities and decide what works best for them.
Good luck, and Train hard!
Chapter 1

Chapter 1: Low Grade Swords:
Arming sword - Traditional - Grade 2 Weaponsmith
The classic double-edged knightly blade. Known as a diamond-section blade, the arming blade has a ridge in the middle, along the length of the blade.
Short Sword - Traditional - Grade 4
An older style of arming blade, featuring an indent along the middle of the blade. This design allows for reinforced edges with the indent reducing the overall weight.
Training sword - Traditional - Grade 6
A blunt blade is used when practicing, so as not to injure the wielders opponent.

Chapter 1: Low Grade Swords:
Arming sword - Traditional - Grade 2 Weaponsmith
The classic double-edged knightly blade. Known as a diamond-section blade, the arming blade has a ridge in the middle, along the length of the blade.
Short Sword - Traditional - Grade 4
An older style of arming blade, featuring an indent along the middle of the blade. This design allows for reinforced edges with the indent reducing the overall weight.
Training sword - Traditional - Grade 6
A blunt blade is used when practicing, so as not to injure the wielders opponent.
Chapter 2

Chapter 2 - Higher end Swords
These swords are for higher grade Weaponsmiths. Not pictured is the Zweihander, which i have no perfect -yet-, at the time of this writing. Hilts will be covered in another chapter.
Claymore - Traditional - Grade 10
The claymore is of Bisclavret design. A very wide and relatively short two-handed blade that is manouverable enough to be used easily in single combat.
Backsword - Traditional - Grade 14
A modern design that features a full, front edge and a partial back edge. As the back edge is not sharp along most of the length, this blade can be thicker and stronger.
(future editions will have more blueprints)

Chapter 2 - Higher end Swords
These swords are for higher grade Weaponsmiths. Not pictured is the Zweihander, which i have no perfect -yet-, at the time of this writing. Hilts will be covered in another chapter.
Claymore - Traditional - Grade 10
The claymore is of Bisclavret design. A very wide and relatively short two-handed blade that is manouverable enough to be used easily in single combat.
Backsword - Traditional - Grade 14
A modern design that features a full, front edge and a partial back edge. As the back edge is not sharp along most of the length, this blade can be thicker and stronger.
(future editions will have more blueprints)
Chapter 3

Chapter 3: Low grade Fencing Swords
Fencing swords are much more difficult to create, so 'Low Grade' is a subjective term in this case. One must be a minimum of grade 11 to create even the most basic Fencing blade. Keep up the hardwork and practice, you'll perfect the more difficult blades soon.
Side-sword - Fencing - Grade 11
An early evolutionary step from the arming sword to the rapier. It features a narrower, single-edged blade with a sharp point designed for effective cutting and thrusting.
The Foil - Fencing - Grade 12
The foil is a fencing blade, with the end capped, to avoid injuries.
Tuck - Fencing - Grade 13
Deviating slightly from the longsword, this weapon is intended to be used against heavily armored opponents. The long blade, consisting of only a point with almost no cutting edge, is stiff and acutely pointed, perfect for finding weak points.

Chapter 3: Low grade Fencing Swords
Fencing swords are much more difficult to create, so 'Low Grade' is a subjective term in this case. One must be a minimum of grade 11 to create even the most basic Fencing blade. Keep up the hardwork and practice, you'll perfect the more difficult blades soon.
Side-sword - Fencing - Grade 11
An early evolutionary step from the arming sword to the rapier. It features a narrower, single-edged blade with a sharp point designed for effective cutting and thrusting.
The Foil - Fencing - Grade 12
The foil is a fencing blade, with the end capped, to avoid injuries.
Tuck - Fencing - Grade 13
Deviating slightly from the longsword, this weapon is intended to be used against heavily armored opponents. The long blade, consisting of only a point with almost no cutting edge, is stiff and acutely pointed, perfect for finding weak points.
Chapter 4

Chapter 4: High end Fencing Swords
For master smiths, and master fencers, and even those that pretend to be master fencers, these blades are most likely to be the ones requested. Learn them well!
Cutlass - Fencing - Grade 15
A stout slashing sword, similar to a sabre. Favored by sailors for the fact that it can slash through heavy rope, canvas and wood, it also requires less training than a rapier or small sword to use effectively.
Rapier - Fencing - Grade 16
A long, relatively narrow (but thick) blade, that sacrifices cutting power for greater reach and thrusting ability. A properly measured rapier blade should reach from the ground to bottom of the wielders ribs. The rapier blade can be quite unwieldy, and is of little use in close quarters.
Sabre - Fencing - Grade 18
The fastest of cutting sword blades, the sabre is a wedge-shaped, curved blade. A footmans sabre is generally fairly straight, and a horsemans sabre is dramatically curved, so the wielder can keep hold of the weapon while striking at the gallop.

Chapter 4: High end Fencing Swords
For master smiths, and master fencers, and even those that pretend to be master fencers, these blades are most likely to be the ones requested. Learn them well!
Cutlass - Fencing - Grade 15
A stout slashing sword, similar to a sabre. Favored by sailors for the fact that it can slash through heavy rope, canvas and wood, it also requires less training than a rapier or small sword to use effectively.
Rapier - Fencing - Grade 16
A long, relatively narrow (but thick) blade, that sacrifices cutting power for greater reach and thrusting ability. A properly measured rapier blade should reach from the ground to bottom of the wielders ribs. The rapier blade can be quite unwieldy, and is of little use in close quarters.
Sabre - Fencing - Grade 18
The fastest of cutting sword blades, the sabre is a wedge-shaped, curved blade. A footmans sabre is generally fairly straight, and a horsemans sabre is dramatically curved, so the wielder can keep hold of the weapon while striking at the gallop.
Chapter 5

Chapter 5 HILTS:
Choosing the right hilt for a sword is ESSENTIAL!
There are five main types of hilts with many variations and alterations. But the five basic types are:
Bar hilt: A simple cruciform device that serves to protect the wielders hand without getting in the way during fighting. This is an older style of guard, popular on large two-handed swords and antiques.
Crossguard: Also known as a knucklebow, a bar or strip protecting the front of the hand. Knucklebows are useful for swords that are often carried everyday, as the guard is flat and doesn't get in the way. For this reason, knucklebowed swords are also very fast to draw.
Bell: A development of the knucklebow. The strip protecting the hand is widened and curved around the wielders knuckles. This style of guard is popular on pirate cutlasses, and all other fencing weapons.
Basket Hilt: An intricate cage surrounds the hilt, protecting the wielder's hand. This is the hilt of choice for the Bisclavret and due to their close-fitting nature are best on cutting, rather than thrusting swords.
Swept hilt: I cant make these yet, but i'm sure they are very stylish. Wish i learn this schematic, i'll update this edition.
As you can see, putting a plain bar hilt on a cutlass or rapier, is an insult to the blade. A fencing basket hilt on a big two handed sword like a claymore is equally distasteful. Be mindful of what you choose.

Choosing the right hilt for a sword is ESSENTIAL!
There are five main types of hilts with many variations and alterations. But the five basic types are:
Bar hilt: A simple cruciform device that serves to protect the wielders hand without getting in the way during fighting. This is an older style of guard, popular on large two-handed swords and antiques.

Bell: A development of the knucklebow. The strip protecting the hand is widened and curved around the wielders knuckles. This style of guard is popular on pirate cutlasses, and all other fencing weapons.
Basket Hilt: An intricate cage surrounds the hilt, protecting the wielder's hand. This is the hilt of choice for the Bisclavret and due to their close-fitting nature are best on cutting, rather than thrusting swords.
Swept hilt: I cant make these yet, but i'm sure they are very stylish. Wish i learn this schematic, i'll update this edition.
As you can see, putting a plain bar hilt on a cutlass or rapier, is an insult to the blade. A fencing basket hilt on a big two handed sword like a claymore is equally distasteful. Be mindful of what you choose.
the spine of the book
The spine of the book is made from blue grey leather.

Core:Properties.Core:Property: X[M] \$delay(2, TRUE, "030f"); EmitTo( \$actor, "The book does not react to you in any way except to look more daunting and self-assured in its knowledge.");
